DataElement.preferredName: Tissue Processing Paraffin Embedding Temperature Unit of Measure Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The code representing the temperature unit of measure.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Cleaning and preparation of tissues for further use in biological products._A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily._To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination._A measure of the average kinetic energy of a system of particles. Temperature may be quantified, in the context of thermodynamics, as the potential of one system to transfer thermal energy to another system until both systems reach a state of thermal equilibrium.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Cleaning and preparation of tissues for further use in biological products.

Concepts.definition: Cleaning and preparation of tissues for further use in biological products.

Property.preferredDefinition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.:To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination.:the degree of hotness or coldness of a body or environment.

Concepts.definition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.
To surround an object with a firm chemical substance such as wax or resin, in order to perform cutting of thin sections for microscopic examination.

A measure of the average kinetic energy of a system of particles. Temperature may be quantified, in the context of thermodynamics, as the potential of one system to transfer thermal energy to another system until both systems reach a state of thermal equilibrium.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Concepts linked to Tissue Banking and Pathology activities

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: All codes that represent the temperature unit of measure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The temperature scale defined by the values 0 degree Celsius for the freezing point of water and 100 degrees Celsius for the boiling point of water.  The Celsius degree (C) is the same size as a Kelvin and equal to (F - 32)/1.8.

Concepts.definition: The temperature scale defined by the values 0 degree Celsius for the freezing point of water and 100 degrees Celsius for the boiling point of water.  The Celsius degree (C) is the same size as a Kelvin and equal to (F - 32)/1.8.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not acquired, gained or come to the possession.

Concepts.definition: Not acquired, gained or come to the possession.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A unit of temperature of the temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is 32 degrees and the boiling point is 212 degrees, placing the boiling and melting points of water 180 degrees apart. One degree Fahrenheit is 5/9ths of a kelvin (or of a degree Celsius), and minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit is equal to minus 40 degrees Celsius.

Concepts.definition: A unit of temperature of the temperature scale designed so that the freezing point of water is 32 degrees and the boiling point is 212 degrees, placing the boiling and melting points of water 180 degrees apart. One degree Fahrenheit is 5/9ths of a kelvin (or of a degree Celsius), and minus 40 degrees Fahrenheit is equal to minus 40 degrees Celsius.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
